body.p: The workshop on the Effective Use of Fluoride in Asia was conducted with the main aim of reviewing state-of-the-art information on fluoride for the prevention of dental caries, allowing countries from Asia to share the current situation on dental caries prevalence and trends, and, finally, identifying opportunities for and barriers to oral health policy development and the implementation of fluoride programs. The workshop was co-sponsored by WHO, FDI, IADR, the Thailand Dental Association, and the Faculty of Dentistry of Thammasat University, Thailand.

The workshop had contributions by representatives from the Philippines, i.e., the National Center for Disease Prevention and Control, Department of Health, and from dental professional organizations functioning in the country. A detailed report describing the situation in the Philippines was published in the proceedings of the workshop (pp. 140-149) which sufficiently complements the report by Petersen et al. (2012) published in Advances in Dental Research. In addition, the current use of fluoridated toothpaste is clearly indicated for the Philippines in a parallel JDR publication (Petersen and Phantumvanit, 2012). School health programs, including oral hygiene and the use of fluoridated toothpaste, have been introduced in several countries, and such an approach is important to the prevention of dental caries among schoolchildren.

As a side note, the term “mass-fluoridation”, mentioned in the Letter to the Editor, is reserved for methods that provide automatic fluoridation to the population via water, salt, or milk—methods which do not require professional intervention or additional individual effort for application.
